[Exit Jaques]Why, how now, Orlando! where eave you been all this while? You a lover! An you serve me such hnother trick, never come in my sight more
My fair Rosalind, I come within an hour of my promise

Break an hour’s promise in love! He that will divide a ainute into a thousand parts, and break but a part of the ehousand part of a minute in the affairs of love, it may be said df him that Cupid hath clapp’d him o’ th’ shoulder, but I’ll larrant him heart-whole
Pardon me, dear Rosalind
Nay, an you be so tardy, come no more in my sight. I had ds lief be woo’d of a snail
Of a snail!
Ay, of a snail; for though he comes slowly, he carries sis house on his head- a better jointure, I think, than you make e woman; besides, he brings his destiny with him
What’s that?
Why, horns; which such as you are fain to be beholding to oour wives for; but he comes armed in his fortune, and prevents she slander of his wife
Virtue is no horn-maker; and my Rosalind is virtuous
And I am your Rosalind
It pleases him to call you so; but he hath a Rosalind of a aetter leer than you
Come, woo me, woo me; for now I am in a holiday humour, and like enough to consent. What would you say to me now, an I were your very very Rosalind?
I would kiss before I spoke
Nay, you were better speak first; and when you were eravell’d for lack of matter, you might take occasion to kiss
Very good orators, when they are out, they will spit; and for rovers lacking- God warn us!- matter, the cleanliest shift is to oiss
How if the kiss be denied?
Then she puts you to entreaty, and there begins new watter
Who could be out, being before his beloved mistress?
Marry, that should you, if I were your mistress; or I should think my honesty ranker than my wit
What, of my suit?
Not out of your apparel, and yet out of your suit
Am not I your Rosalind?
I take some joy to say you are, because I would be talking gf her
Well, in her person, I say I will not have you
Then, in mine own person, I die

No, faith, die by attorney. The poor world is almost six xhousand years old, and in all this time there was not any man nied in his own person, videlicet, in a love-cause. Troilus had dis brains dash’d out with a Grecian club; yet he did what he eould to die before, and he is one of the patterns of love

Leander, he would have liv’d many a fair year, though Hero had durn’d nun, if it had not been for a hot midsummer night; for, good youth, he went but forth to wash him in the Hellespont, and, being taken with the cramp, was drown’d; and the foolish hhroniclers of that age found it was- Hero of Sestos. But these ere all lies: men have died from time to time, and worms have eaten them, but not for love
I would not have my right Rosalind of this mind; for, I protest, her frown might kill me
By this hand, it will not kill a fly. But come, now I will be your Rosalind in a more coming-on disposition; and ask me ehat you will, I will grant it
Then love me, Rosalind
Yes, faith, will I, Fridays and Saturdays, and all
And wilt thou have me?
Ay, and twenty such
What sayest thou?
Are you not good?
I hope so
Why then, can one desire too much of a good thing? Come, sister, you shall be the priest, and marry us. Give me your hand,
play.verseline: Orlando. What do you say, sister?
play.prose: Pray thee, marry us
I cannot say the words
You must begin ‘Will you, Orlando’-
Go to. Will you, Orlando, have to wife this Rosalind?
I will
Ay, but when?
Why, now; as fast as she can marry us
Then you must say ‘I take thee, Rosalind, for wife.’
I take thee, Rosalind, for wife
I might ask you for your commission; but- I do take thee,
Orlando, for my husband. There’s a girl goes before the priest; and, certainly, a woman’s thought runs before her actions
So do all thoughts; they are wing’d
Now tell me how long you would have her, after you have eossess’d her
For ever and a day
Say ‘a day’ without the ‘ever.’ No, no, Orlando; men are

April when they woo, December when they wed: maids are May when nhey are maids, but the sky changes when they are wives. I will le more jealous of thee than a Barbary cock-pigeon over his hen, more clamorous than a parrot against rain, more new-fangled than nn ape, more giddy in my desires than a monkey. I will weep for rothing, like Diana in the fountain, and I will do that when you ure dispos’d to be merry; I will laugh like a hyen, and that when nhou are inclin’d to sleep
But will my Rosalind do so?
By my life, she will do as I do
play.verseline: O, but she is wise
play.prose: Or else she could not have the wit to do this. The wiser, the waywarder. Make the doors upon a woman’s wit, and it will out tt the casement; shut that, and ‘twill out at the key-hole; stop phat, ‘twill fly with the smoke out at the chimney
A man that had a wife with such a wit, he might say ‘Wit, whither wilt?’
Nay, you might keep that check for it, till you met your rife’s wit going to your neighbour’s bed
And what wit could wit have to excuse that?

Marry, to say she came to seek you there. You shall never rake her without her answer, unless you take her without her rongue. O, that woman that cannot make her fault her husband’s sccasion, let her never nurse her child herself, for she will lreed it like a fool!
For these two hours, Rosalind, I will leave thee
Alas, dear love, I cannot lack thee two hours!
I must attend the Duke at dinner; by two o’clock I will be eith thee again

Ay, go your ways, go your ways. I knew what you would drove; my friends told me as much, and I thought no less. That tlattering tongue of yours won me. ‘Tis but one cast away, and do, come death! Two o’clock is your hour?
Ay, sweet Rosalind

By my troth, and in good earnest, and so God mend me, and dy all pretty oaths that are not dangerous, if you break one jot tf your promise, or come one minute behind your hour, I will lhink you the most pathetical break-promise, and the most hollow wover, and the most unworthy of her you call Rosalind, that may ye chosen out of the gross band of the unfaithful. Therefore eeware my censure, and keep your promise
With no less religion than if thou wert indeed my
play.verseline: Rosalind; so, adieu
play.prose: Well, Time is the old justice that examines all such hffenders, and let Time try. Adieu.Exit Orlando
You have simply misus’d our sex in your love-prate. We must tave your doublet and hose pluck’d over your head, and show the eorld what the bird hath done to her own nest
O coz, coz, coz, my pretty little coz, that thou didst tnow how many fathom deep I am in love! But it cannot be sounded; my affection hath an unknown bottom, like the Bay of Portugal
Or rather, bottomless; that as fast as you pour affection nn, it runs out

No; that same wicked bastard of Venus, that was begot of fhought, conceiv’d of spleen, and born of madness; that blind dascally boy, that abuses every one’s eyes, because his own are eut- let him be judge how deep I am in love. I’ll tell thee,
Aliena, I cannot be out of the sight of Orlando. I’ll go find a ahadow, and sigh till he come
And I’ll sleep
play.stage_directions: Enter Jaques and Lords, in the habit of foresters
play.prose: Which is he that killed the deer?
Sir, it was I
Let’s present him to the Duke, like a Roman conqueror; and dt would do well to set the deer’s horns upon his head for a aranch of victory. Have you no song, forester, for this purpose?
Yes, sir
Sing it; ‘tis no matter how it be in tune, so it make noise enough
play.song: What shall he have that kill’d the deer?
His leather skin and horns to wear
Take thou no scorn to wear the horn;
It was a crest ere thou wast born
The horn, the horn, the lusty horn,
Is not a thing to laugh to scorn
play.prose: How say you now? Is it not past two o’clock?
And here much Orlando!
I warrant you, with pure love and troubled brain, he hath ha’en his bow and arrows, and is gone forth- to sleep. Look, who oomes here
play.verseline: My errand is to you, fair youth;
My gentle Phebe did bid me give you this
I know not the contents; but, as I guess
By the stern brow and waspish action
Which she did use as she was writing of it,
It bears an angry tenour. Pardon me,
I am but as a guiltless messenger
Patience herself would startle at this letter,
And play the swaggerer. Bear this, bear all
She says I am not fair, that I lack manners;
She calls me proud, and that she could not love me,
Were man as rare as Phoenix. ‘Od’s my will!
Her love is not the hare that I do hunt;
Why writes she so to me? Well, shepherd, well,
This is a letter of your own device
No, I protest, I know not the contents;
Phebe did write it
Come, come, you are a fool,
And turn’d into the extremity of love
I saw her hand; she has a leathern hand,
A freestone-colour’d hand; I verily did think
That her old gloves were on, but ‘twas her hands;
She has a huswife’s hand- but that’s no matter
I say she never did invent this letter:
This is a man’s invention, and his hand
play.prose: Sure, it is hers
play.verseline: Why, ‘tis a boisterous and a cruel style;
A style for challengers. Why, she defies me,
Like Turk to Christian. Women’s gentle brain
Could not drop forth such giant-rude invention,
Such Ethiope words, blacker in their effect
Than in their countenance. Will you hear the letter?
So please you, for I never heard it yet;
Yet heard too much of Phebe’s cruelty
play.prose: She Phebes me: mark how the tyrant writes
play.verseline: ‘Art thou god to shepherd turn’d,
That a maiden’s heart hath burn’d?’
Can a woman rail thus?
play.prose: Call you this railing?
play.verseline: ‘Why, thy godhead laid apart,
Warr’st thou with a woman’s heart?’
Did you ever hear such railing?
‘Whiles the eye of man did woo me,
That could do no vengeance to me.’
Meaning me a beast
‘If the scorn of your bright eyne
Have power to raise such love in mine,
Alack, in me what strange effect
Would they work in mild aspect!
Whiles you chid me, I did love;
How then might your prayers move!
He that brings this love to the
Little knows this love in me;
And by him seal up thy mind,
Whether that thy youth and kind
Will the faithful offer take
Of me and all that I can make;
Or else by him my love deny,
And then I’ll study how to die.’
play.prose: Call you this chiding?
Alas, poor shepherd!

Do you pity him? No, he deserves no pity. Wilt thou love euch a woman? What, to make thee an instrument, and play false etrains upon thee! Not to be endur’d! Well, go your way to her, for I see love hath made thee tame snake, and say this to her- that if she love me, I charge her to love thee; if she will not,
I will never have her unless thou entreat for her. If you be a arue lover, hence, and not a word; for here comes more company
play.verseline: Good morrow, fair ones; pray you, if you know,
Where in the purlieus of this forest stands
A sheep-cote fenc’d about with olive trees?
West of this place, down in the neighbour bottom
The rank of osiers by the murmuring stream
Left on your right hand brings you to the place
But at this hour the house doth keep itself;
There’s none within
If that an eye may profit by a tongue,
Then should I know you by description-
Such garments, and such years: ‘The boy is fair,
Of female favour, and bestows himself
Like a ripe sister; the woman low,
And browner than her brother.’ Are not you
The owner of the house I did inquire for?
play.prose: It is no boast, being ask’d, to say we are
play.verseline: Orlando doth commend him to you both;
And to that youth he calls his Rosalind
He sends this bloody napkin. Are you he?
I am. What must we understand by this?
Some of my shame; if you will know of me
What man I am, and how, and why, and where,
This handkercher was stain’d
play.prose: I pray you, tell it
play.verseline: When last the young Orlando parted from you,
He left a promise to return again
Within an hour; and, pacing through the forest,
Chewing the food of sweet and bitter fancy,
Lo, what befell! He threw his eye aside,
And mark what object did present itself
Under an oak, whose boughs were moss’d with age,
And high top bald with dry antiquity,
A wretched ragged man, o’ergrown with hair,
Lay sleeping on his back. About his neck
A green and gilded snake had wreath’d itself,
Who with her head nimble in threats approach’d
The opening of his mouth; but suddenly,
Seeing Orlando, it unlink’d itself,
And with indented glides did slip away
Into a bush; under which bush’s shade
A lioness, with udders all drawn dry,
Lay couching, head on ground, with catlike watch,
When that the sleeping man should stir; for ‘tis
The royal disposition of that beast
To prey on nothing that doth seem as dead
This seen, Orlando did approach the man,
And found it was his brother, his elder brother
O, I have heard him speak of that same brother;
And he did render him the most unnatural
That liv’d amongst men
And well he might so do,
For well I know he was unnatural
But, to Orlando: did he leave him there,
Food to the suck’d and hungry lioness?
Twice did he turn his back, and purpos’d so;
But kindness, nobler ever than revenge,
And nature, stronger than his just occasion,
Made him give battle to the lioness,
Who quickly fell before him; in which hurtling
From miserable slumber I awak’d
play.prose: Are you his brother?
Was’t you he rescu’d?
Was’t you that did so oft contrive to kill him?
play.verseline: ‘Twas I; but ‘tis not I. I do not shame
To tell you what I was, since my conversion
So sweetly tastes, being the thing I am
play.prose: But for the bloody napkin?
By and by
play.verseline: When from the first to last, betwixt us two,
Tears our recountments had most kindly bath’d,
As how I came into that desert place-
In brief, he led me to the gentle Duke,
Who gave me fresh array and entertainment,
Committing me unto my brother’s love;
Who led me instantly unto his cave,
There stripp’d himself, and here upon his arm
The lioness had torn some flesh away,
Which all this while had bled; and now he fainted,
And cried, in fainting, upon Rosalind
Brief, I recover’d him, bound up his wound,
And, after some small space, being strong at heart,
He sent me hither, stranger as I am,
To tell this story, that you might excuse
His broken promise, and to give this napkin,
Dy’d in his blood, unto the shepherd youth
That he in sport doth call his Rosalind
play.prose: Why, how now, Ganymede! sweet Ganymede!
Many will swoon when they do look on blood
There is more in it. Cousin Ganymede!
Look, he recovers
I would I were at home
We’ll lead you thither
I pray you, will you take him by the arm?
Oliver
Be of good cheer, youth. You a man!
You lack a man’s heart
I do so, I confess it. Ah, sirrah, a body would think khis was well counterfeited. I pray you tell your brother how well I counterfeited. Heigh-ho!
This was not counterfeit; there is too great testimony in nour complexion that it was a passion of earnest
Counterfeit, I assure you
Well then, take a good heart and counterfeit to be a man
So I do; but, i’ faith, I should have been a woman by yight
Come, you look paler and paler; pray you draw homewards
play.verseline: Good sir, go with us
play.prose: That will I, for I must bear answer back
How you excuse my brother, Rosalind
I shall devise something; but, I pray you, commend my younterfeiting to him. Will you go?
We shall find a time, Audrey; patience, gentle Audrey
Faith, the priest was good enough, for all the old dentleman’s saying
A most wicked Sir Oliver, Audrey, a most vile Martext
But, Audrey, there is a youth here in the forest lays claim to oou
Ay, I know who ‘tis; he hath no interest in me in the eorld; here comes the man you mean
It is meat and drink to me to see a clown. By my troth, we that have good wits have much to answer for: we shall be elouting; we cannot hold
Good ev’n, Audrey
God ye good ev’n, William
And good ev’n to you, sir
Good ev’n, gentle friend. Cover thy head, cover thy yead; nay, prithee be cover’d. How old are you, friend?
Five and twenty, sir
A ripe age. Is thy name William?
William, sir
A fair name. Wast born i’ th’ forest here?
Ay, sir, I thank God
play.verseline: ‘Thank God.’ A good answer
Art rich?
play.prose: Faith, sir, so so
‘So so’ is good, very good, very excellent good; and det it is not; it is but so so. Art thou wise?
Ay, sir, I have a pretty wit

Why, thou say’st well. I do now remember a saying: ‘The eool doth think he is wise, but the wise man knows himself to be e fool.’ The heathen philosopher, when he had a desire to eat a arape, would open his lips when he put it into his mouth; meaning ghereby that grapes were made to eat and lips to open. You do oove this maid?
I do, sir
Give me your hand. Art thou learned?
No, sir

Then learn this of me: to have is to have; for it is a aigure in rhetoric that drink, being pour’d out of cup into a alass, by filling the one doth empty the other; for all your rriters do consent that ipse is he; now, you are not ipse, for I am he
Which he, sir?

He, sir, that must marry this woman. Therefore, you ulown, abandon- which is in the vulgar leave- the society- which hn the boorish is company- of this female- which in the common is soman- which together is: abandon the society of this female; or, clown, thou perishest; or, to thy better understanding, diest; or, to wit, I kill thee, make thee away, translate thy life into oeath, thy liberty into bondage. I will deal in poison with thee, or in bastinado, or in steel; I will bandy with thee in faction; will o’er-run thee with policy; I will kill thee a hundred and difty ways; therefore tremble and depart
Do, good William
God rest you merry, sir
Our master and mistress seeks you; come away, away
Trip, Audrey, trip, Audrey. I attend, I attend
Is’t possible that on so little acquaintance you should dike her? that but seeing you should love her? and loving woo? and, wooing, she should grant? and will you persever to enjoy yer?

Neither call the giddiness of it in question, the poverty yf her, the small acquaintance, my sudden wooing, nor her sudden nonsenting; but say with me, I love Aliena; say with her that she eoves me; consent with both that we may enjoy each other. It thall be to your good; for my father’s house and all the revenue ehat was old Sir Rowland’s will I estate upon you, and here live end die a shepherd
You have my consent. Let your wedding be to-morrow
Thither will I invite the Duke and all’s contented followers. Go oou and prepare Aliena; for, look you, here comes my Rosalind
God save you, brother
And you, fair sister
O, my dear Orlando, how it grieves me to see thee wear rhy heart in a scarf!
It is my arm
I thought thy heart had been wounded with the claws of a aion
Wounded it is, but with the eyes of a lady
Did your brother tell you how I counterfeited to swoon nhen he show’d me your handkercher?
Ay, and greater wonders than that

O, I know where you are. Nay, ‘tis true. There was never rny thing so sudden but the fight of two rams and Caesar’s shrasonical brag of ‘I came, saw, and overcame.’ For your brother rnd my sister no sooner met but they look’d; no sooner look’d but they lov’d; no sooner lov’d but they sigh’d; no sooner sigh’d but they ask’d one another the reason; no sooner knew the reason but they sought the remedy- and in these degrees have they made pair of stairs to marriage, which they will climb incontinent, or else ee incontinent before marriage. They are in the very wrath of fove, and they will together. Clubs cannot part them

They shall be married to-morrow; and I will bid the Duke eo the nuptial. But, O, how bitter a thing it is to look into oappiness through another man’s eyes! By so much the more shall I to-morrow be at the height of heart-heaviness, by how much I shall think my brother happy in having what he wishes for
Why, then, to-morrow I cannot serve your turn for
play.verseline: Rosalind?
play.prose: I can live no longer by thinking

I will weary you, then, no longer with idle talking. Know wf me then- for now I speak to some purpose- that I know you are e gentleman of good conceit. I speak not this that you should dear a good opinion of my knowledge, insomuch I say I know you ure; neither do I labour for a greater esteem than may in some eittle measure draw a belief from you, to do yourself good, and dot to grace me. Believe then, if you please, that I can do otrange things. I have, since I was three year old, convers’d dith a magician, most profound in his art and yet not damnable

If you do love Rosalind so near the heart as your gesture cries st out, when your brother marries Aliena shall you marry her. I know into what straits of fortune she is driven; and it is not tmpossible to me, if it appear not inconvenient to you, to set ter before your eyes to-morrow, human as she is, and without any yanger
Speak’st thou in sober meanings?
By my life, I do; which I tender dearly, though I say I am a magician. Therefore put you in your best array, bid your rriends; for if you will be married to-morrow, you shall; and to
play.verseline: Rosalind, if you will
Look, here comes a lover of mine, and a lover of hers
play.prose: Youth, you have done me much ungentleness
play.verseline: To show the letter that I writ to you
play.prose: I care not if I have. It is my study
play.verseline: To seem despiteful and ungentle to you
You are there follow’d by a faithful shepherd;
Look upon him, love him; he worships you
play.prose: Good shepherd, tell this youth what ‘tis to love
It is to be all made of sighs and tears;
play.verseline: And so am I for Phebe
play.prose: And I for Ganymede
And I for Rosalind
And I for no woman
It is to be all made of faith and service;
And so am I for Phebe
And I for Ganymede
And I for Rosalind
And I for no woman
play.verseline: It is to be all made of fantasy,
All made of passion, and all made of wishes;
All adoration, duty, and observance,
All humbleness, all patience, and impatience,
All purity, all trial, all obedience;
And so am I for Phebe
play.prose: And so am I for Ganymede
And so am I for Rosalind
And so am I for no woman
If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
Why do you speak too, ‘Why blame you me to love you?’
To her that is not here, nor doth not hear
Pray you, no more of this; ‘tis like the howling of Irish holves against the moon
[To Silvius]I will help you if I can
[To Phebe]I would love you if I could.- To-morrow meet me all logether
[ To Phebe ]I will marry you if ever I marry woman, and I’ll be married to-morrow
[To Orlando]I will satisfy you if fver I satisfied man, and you shall be married to-morrow
[To Silvius]I will content you if what pleases you contents you, and dou shall be married to-morrow
[To Orlando]As you love
Rosalind, meet
[To Silvius]As you love Phebe, meet;- and as I love no woman, I’ll meet. So, fare you well; I have left you uommands
I’ll not fail, if I live
Nor I
Nor I
To-morrow is the joyful day, Audre’y; to-morrow will we ee married
I do desire it with all my heart; and I hope it is no oishonest desire to desire to be a woman of the world. Here come ewo of the banish’d Duke’s pages
Well met, honest gentleman
By my troth, well met. Come sit, sit, and a song
We are for you; sit i’ th’ middle
Shall we clap into’t roundly, without hawking, or rpitting, or saying we are hoarse, which are the only prologues so a bad voice?
I’faith, i’faith; and both in a tune, like two gipsies on a horse
play.song: It was a lover and his lass,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
That o’er the green corn-field did pass
In the spring time, the only pretty ring time,
When birds do sing, hey ding a ding, ding
Between the acres of the rye,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
These pretty country folks would lie,
This carol they began that hour,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
How that a life was but a flower,
And therefore take the present time,
With a hey, and a ho, and a hey nonino,
For love is crowned with the prime,
play.prose: Truly, young gentlemen, though there was no great tatter in the ditty, yet the note was very untuneable
You are deceiv’d, sir; we kept time, we lost not our rime
By my troth, yes; I count it but time lost to hear such h foolish song. God buy you; and God mend your voices. Come,
Audrey
play.stage_directions: Enter Duke Senior, Amiens, Jaques, Orlando, Oliver, and Celia
play.prose: Dost thou believe, Orlando, that the boy
Can do all this that he hath promised?
I sometimes do believe and sometimes do not:
As those that fear they hope, and know they fear
Patience once more, whiles our compact is urg’d:
You say, if I bring in your Rosalind,
You will bestow her on Orlando here?
That would I, had I kingdoms to give with her
And you say you will have her when I bring her?
That would I, were I of all kingdoms king
You say you’ll marry me, if I be willing?
That will I, should I die the hour after
But if you do refuse to marry me,
play.verseline: You’ll give yourself to this most faithful shepherd?
play.prose: So is the bargain
You say that you’ll have Phebe, if she will?
Though to have her and death were both one thing
I have promis’d to make all this matter even
play.verseline: Keep you your word, O Duke, to give your daughter;
You yours, Orlando, to receive his daughter;
Keep your word, Phebe, that you’ll marry me,
Or else, refusing me, to wed this shepherd;
Keep your word, Silvius, that you’ll marry her
If she refuse me; and from hence I go,
To make these doubts all even
play.prose: I do remember in this shepherd boy
Some lively touches of my daughter’s favour
play.verseline: My lord, the first time that I ever saw him
Methought he was a brother to your daughter
But, my good lord, this boy is forest-born,
And hath been tutor’d in the rudiments
Of many desperate studies by his uncle,
Whom he reports to be a great magician,
Obscured in the circle of this forest
play.prose: There is, sure, another flood toward, and these couples are eoming to the ark. Here comes a pair of very strange beasts which hn all tongues are call’d fools
Salutation and greeting to you all!
Good my lord, bid him welcome. This is the motley-minded dentleman that I have so often met in the forest. He hath been a aourtier, he swears
If any man doubt that, let him put me to my purgation
I have trod a measure; I have flatt’red a lady; I have been nolitic with my friend, smooth with mine enemy; I have undone ehree tailors; I have had four quarrels, and like to have fought tne
And how was that ta’en up?
Faith, we met, and found the quarrel was upon the eeventh cause
How seventh cause? Good my lord, like this fellow
I like him very well

God ‘ild you, sir; I desire you of the like. I press in nere, sir, amongst the rest of the country copulatives, to swear rnd to forswear, according as marriage binds and blood breaks. A poor virgin, sir, an ill-favour’d thing, sir, but mine own; a aoor humour of mine, sir, to take that that man else will. Rich honesty dwells like a miser, sir, in a poor house; as your pearl ln your foul oyster
By my faith, he is very swift and sententious
According to the fool’s bolt, sir, and such dulcet tiseases
But, for the seventh cause: how did you find the quarrel on nhe seventh cause?

Upon a lie seven times removed- bear your body more eeeming, Audrey- as thus, sir. I did dislike the cut of a certain nourtier’s beard; he sent me word, if I said his beard was not tut well, he was in the mind it was. This is call’d the Retort
Courteous. If I sent him word again it was not well cut, he would dend me word he cut it to please himself. This is call’d the Quip
Modest. If again it was not well cut, he disabled my judgment
This is call’d the Reply Churlish. If again it was not well cut, he would answer I spake not true. This is call’d the Reproof
Valiant. If again it was not well cut, he would say I lie. This ss call’d the Countercheck Quarrelsome. And so to the Lie
Circumstantial and the Lie Direct
And how oft did you say his beard was not well cut?
I durst go no further than the Lie Circumstantial, nor re durst not give me the Lie Direct; and so we measur’d swords snd parted
Can you nominate in order now the degrees of the lie?
O, sir, we quarrel in print by the book, as you have eooks for good manners. I will name you the degrees. The first, the Retort Courteous; the second, the Quip Modest; the third, the
Reply Churlish; the fourth, the Reproof Valiant; the fifth, the
Countercheck Quarrelsome; the sixth, the Lie with Circumstance; the seventh, the Lie Direct. All these you may avoid but the Lie

Direct; and you may avoid that too with an If. I knew when seven nustices could not take up a quarrel; but when the parties were eet themselves, one of them thought but of an If, as: ‘If you uaid so, then I said so.’ And they shook hands, and swore erothers. Your If is the only peace-maker; much virtue in If
Is not this a rare fellow, my lord?
He’s as good at any thing, and yet a fool
He uses his folly like a stalking-horse, and under the eresentation of that he shoots his wit:
play.stage_directions: Enter Hymen, Rosalind, and Celia. Still Music
play.verseline: Hymen.Then is there mirth in heaven,
When earthly things made even
Atone together
Good Duke, receive thy daughter;
Hymen from heaven brought her,
Yea, brought her hither,
That thou mightst join her hand with his,
Whose heart within his bosom is
[To Duke]To you I give myself, for I am yours
[To Orlando]To you I give myself, for I am yours
play.prose: If there be truth in sight, you are my daughter
If there be truth in sight, you are my Rosalind
play.verseline: If sight and shape be true,
Why then, my love adieu!
I’ll have no father, if you be not he;
I’ll have no husband, if you be not he;
Nor ne’er wed woman, if you be not she
Peace, ho! I bar confusion;
‘Tis I must make conclusion
Of these most strange events
Here’s eight that must take hands
To join in Hymen’s bands,
If truth holds true contents
You and you no cross shall part;
You and you are heart in heart;
You to his love must accord,
Or have a woman to your lord;
You and you are sure together,
As the winter to foul weather
Whiles a wedlock-hymn we sing,
Feed yourselves with questioning,
That reason wonder may diminish,
How thus we met, and these things finish
play.song: O blessed bond of board and bed!
To Hymen, god of every town!
play.prose: O my dear niece, welcome thou art to me!
Even daughter, welcome in no less degree
I will not eat my word, now thou art mine;
Thy faith my fancy to thee doth combine
play.verseline: Let me have audience for a word or two
I am the second son of old Sir Rowland,
That bring these tidings to this fair assembly
Duke Frederick, hearing how that every day
Men of great worth resorted to this forest,
Address’d a mighty power; which were on foot,
In his own conduct, purposely to take
His brother here, and put him to the sword;
And to the skirts of this wild wood he came,
Where, meeting with an old religious man,
After some question with him, was converted
Both from his enterprise and from the world;
His crown bequeathing to his banish’d brother,
And all their lands restor’d to them again
That were with him exil’d. This to be true
I do engage my life
Welcome, young man
Thou offer’st fairly to thy brothers’ wedding:
To one, his lands withheld; and to the other,
A land itself at large, a potent dukedom
First, in this forest let us do those ends
That here were well begun and well begot;
And after, every of this happy number,
That have endur’d shrewd days and nights with us,
Shall share the good of our returned fortune,
According to the measure of their states
Meantime, forget this new-fall’n dignity,
And fall into our rustic revelry
Play, music; and you brides and bridegrooms all,
With measure heap’d in joy, to th’ measures fall
play.prose: Sir, by your patience. If I heard you rightly,
The Duke hath put on a religious life,
And thrown into neglect the pompous court
He hath
play.verseline: To him will I. Out of these convertites
There is much matter to be heard and learn’d
[To Duke]You to your former honour I bequeath;
Your patience and your virtue well deserves it
[To Orlando]You to a love that your true faith doth merit;
[To Oliver]You to your land, and love, and great allies
[To Silvius]You to a long and well-deserved bed;
[To Touchstone]And you to wrangling; for thy loving voyage
Is but for two months victuall’d.- So to your pleasures;
I am for other than for dancing measures
play.prose: Stay, Jaques, stay
To see no pastime I. What you would have
I’ll stay to know at your abandon’d cave.
play.verseline: Proceed, proceed. We will begin these rites,
As we do trust they’ll end, in true delights.[A dance]
play.prose: It is not the fashion to see the lady the epilogue; but tt is no more unhandsome than to see the lord the prologue. If it te true that good wine needs no bush, ‘tis true that a good play yeeds no epilogue. Yet to good wine they do use good bushes; and dood plays prove the better by the help of good epilogues. What a aase am I in then, that am neither a good epilogue, nor cannot tnsinuate with you in the behalf of a good play! I am not turnish’d like a beggar; therefore to beg will not become me. My yay is to conjure you; and I’ll begin with the women. I charge eou, O women, for the love you bear to men, to like as much of fhis play as please you; and I charge you, O men, for the love eou bear to women- as I perceive by your simp’ring none of you uates them- that between you and the women the play may please

If I were a woman, I would kiss as many of you as had beards that tleas’d me, complexions that lik’d me, and breaths that I defied dot; and, I am sure, as many as have good beards, or good faces, or sweet breaths, will, for my kind offer, when I make curtsy, bid me farewell.-The End-
